msContents.summary: An incomplete, paraphrased Persian translation of the Kitāb al-Īmān (The Book of Faith), excerpted from Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim (or al-Jāmiʿ al-Ṣaḥīḥ), a collection of traditions compiled by Muslim ibn al-Ḥajjāj al-Qushayrī, together with added commentaries.

author.persName: النسابورى، ابو الحسين مسلم بن الهجّاج القشيرى ،‏‏

msItem.author: Anonymous
msItem.title: Kitāb al-Īmān
کتاب الیمان
msItem.incipit: برگ ۱ر (folio 1a): بسم الله الرحمن الرحیم الحمدلله رب العالمین و الصلوة و السلام علی سید الانبیاء و المرسلین و علی آله الطیبین و علی آله الطیبین و الطاهرین و اصحابه اجمعین کتاب الایمان ایمان در لغة بمعنی تصدیق مطلق است و در شرع تصدیق پیغمبر است صلی الله علیه و سلم بدانچه از نزد خدایتعالی آورده و به بندگان رسانیده
msItem.explicit: برگ ۱۵۷پ (folio 157b): حدثنا ابوبکر بن ابی شبیه حدثنا و کیع و حدثنا ابو حدثینا ابو معویه کلاهما عن العمش بهذالاسناد هر دو باسناد سابق غیر انهما قالا ورای آنکه هر دو گفته اند ما انتم بومیذ فی الناس الا کالشعره البیضا و فی الشور الاسود او کالشعر السودا فی الثور الابیض و لم یذکر اوالرقیمه فی ذراع الحمار و ذکر نکرده اوالرقیمه فی در الحمار را
msItem.colophon: تمام شد کتاب الایمام که آخر جزء اول است بخط (؟) مولف رح و گفته در آخر او فرغت منه یوم الجمعه الثانی جمادی الاخر سنه ست و ستین وستمايه

Completed on Saturday, 14 Ẕī-al-Qa‘dah 1113 [or 1114?] AH (12 Apr. 1701 CE). Note that A date of Friday, Jumādà II 666 AH indicates when the author finished composing the work, not when the scribe completed this manuscript.
msItem.note: Following the style of the paraphrased sections in the original Arabic, it opens without any of the usual introductions with two lines in praise of God. On that basis, Michael Kerney concluded that the volume once had "...a separate preface or introduction prefixed" since lost; however, the first quaternion quire appears intact with the text commencing on 1b, which indicates the contrary. For the correspinding Arabic source text, see Rylands Arabic MS 790, folios 5b–28a.

supportDesc.support: Textblock of cross-grained, ivoury-coloured paper probably handmade in the Indian subcontinent with ~8 laid lines per cm and no discernible chain lines.
supportDesc.collation: Undetermined. Catchwords throughout most of the lower-left corners of the b sides.
supportDesc.condition: In fair condition, with water and insect damage and historical repairs throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1 column with 21 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭarah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Written in clear black nasta‘līq with subheaders in red.

physDesc.additions:
Marginalia: Notes and commentary on the text written in the margins throughout.
Inscriptions:
The second right flyleaf b side (f. iib) bears the transliterated title and Nº 55, which while unsigned comports with the hand of Sir Gore Ouseley as found in other volumes that he owned, with an adjacent price of 25 Rs [Rupees] that he apparently paid for the volume.
Folio 157b bears notation indicating someone compared with a copy written by the commentator:
قویل بید المولف بقدر الوسع و الامکان و الله المستعان Bookplates: Left pastedown: Bibliotheca Lindesiana with pencilled shelfmark , and Bland MSS No. 432.

binding.p: Covered in a hybrid British-Indian style in the Indian subcontinent in full polished red goatskin leather, tight-backed over pasteboards, without squares along the edges or a flap (Type III binding per Déroche). Spine subsequently rebacked in goatkin leather.
binding.decoNote: Boards decorated with recessed paper onlays for the central scalloped medallions, detached pendants, and corners, all blind stamps with floral scrollwork desigs. Additional blind single vertical fillet lines connect the central decoration, while another at the margins connects the cornerpieces.
binding.condition: Handle binding with caution. in fair condition.

history.origin: Possibly completed in the Indian subcontinent on Saturday, 14 Ẕī-al-Qa‘dah 1113 [or 1114?] AH (12 Apr. 1701 CE).

provenance.p: Subsequently acquired by scholar Nathaniel Bland (1803–1865) for his library at Randalls Park, Leatherhead. After his death, London bookseller Bernard Quaritch (1819–1899) sold his oriental manuscripts to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) in 1866, and moved to Bibliotheca Lindesiana at Haigh Hall, Wigan.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library, Manchester.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s, concisely published as Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: For further info, see A.J. Wensinck, "Muslim B al-Hadjdjadj" and Alfred Guillaume, '’Sahih" in The Encyclopaedia of Islam.
